prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

head.headtext: The Employee's Post-Employment Duty of Confidentiality—Consequences for Subsequent Employers

para.paratext: Frequently, claims against a former employee also result in action against the new employer. Taking and using confidential information is clearly a breach of a departing employee's duty of good faith and confidentiality. The following factual circumstances were considered in Service Corp. International (Canada) Ltd. v. Nunes-Pottinger Funeral Service & Crematorium Ltd.[1] The Graham Funeral Home was the only funeral home in Oliver, B.C. until its long time manager Nunes resigned to open a competing business, taking the entire staff with him. As of September 2008, Graham had files containing approximately 300 pre-need contracts. The contract was between the purchaser and an insurance or trust company. When notified of the purchaser's death, the insurance or trust company releases the funds to the designated funeral home, which typically refers to its copy of the contract to determine the details of the goods and services that were ordered. The majority of pre-need contracts held by Graham had been made with one insurer. Those contracts were also the most easily transferred to another funeral home. Copies of more than 200 of those files were made and taken to NP included the information NP needed to contact the clients and persuade them to transfer their contracts. On opening, NP advertised that it could “help you transfer your pre-arranged funeral policy quickly and easily.” The majority of transfers in fact took place within the first three months. Nunes initially denied that NP was in possession of any Graham documents but eventually consented to an order, under which they were to return all documents, including copies, along with other Graham property. Most of the copied files were returned but about 40 had by then been destroyed. The destroyed files were likely the ones for which no transfer had been obtained. Every file that was returned contained a transfer form in favour of NP. The trial judge concluded that Nunes and Pottinger were in clear breach of their duty not to misuse confidential information obtained from their former employer. When a new employer benefits from the misuse of confidential information, that new employer is also liable for the former employer's losses, even if it had no direct knowledge of the employees' breach of duty. The case for liability of the new employer NP was particularly strong because Nunes and Pottinger were not merely new employees but the directing minds of NP which clearly benefited from the transfer of business. Nunes, Pottinger and NP were jointly and severally liable for misuse of confidential information to obtain the transfer of pre-need contracts.[2]

In McDonald & Bychkowski Ltd. v. Lougheed,[3] three of the plaintiff's employees went to work for McLean & Shaw Insurance Inc. Tory was the owner of McLean & Shaw. She says that all times she was working as a director or an officer of McLean & Shaw and that there was no basis for an action against her personally.[4]

The defendants all worked for CMB. Lougheed and Semeniuk resigned. Talbott was fired. All three went to work for McLean & Shaw. The plaintiff alleged that Lougheed and Semeniuk were induced to join McLean & Shaw and that Lougheed, Semeniuk and Talbott then stole business from the plaintiff and used the plaintiff's confidential information to the plaintiff's detriment.[5]

The motion judge observed that there is no legal bar to liability of both a corporation and its owner, even if the owner acts within the course and scope of her employment. What must be alleged, is an overt act; something that takes the owner or employee outside identification with the company. Circumstances that might permit lifting the corporate veil or imposing joint liability might also suffice. The Officer or Director has to exhibit a separate character or identity. Otherwise it is not a case of doubling up, or “tripling up”, as in Said v. Butt. It is a case of either/or. Without alleging anything more than an identity of interest and acts, the action against Tory for inducing breach of contract, fiduciary duty or confidentially have no reasonable prospect of success. It is one or the other: her or McLean & Shaw, on the facts as pleaded. These allegations against the applicant were struck.[6]

In many jurisdictions, actions are increasingly being brought against competitors for “raiding” employees. Given the competitiveness of most industries, this will continue to be an important topic in the future.

The issue of raiding recently came before the Supreme Court of Canada in RBC Dominion Securities Inc. v. Merrill Lynch Canada Inc.[7] Merrill Lynch successfully induced a large portion of RBC's investment advisors to leave RBC and join Merrill Lynch. RBC sued the former employees and also sued Merrill Lynch, inter alia, in tort for inducing RBC staff to terminate their employment contracts without notice and to unfairly compete against RBC. The British Columbia Supreme Court found that Merill Lynch was liable for inducing the employees' breaches of their duties “not to compete unfairly” with RBC and awarded damages accordingly. The Court of Appeal, however, found that there is no general legal obligation on the part of an employee, upon leaving his employ, “not to compete unfairly” and, consequently, there could be no inducement to breach such an obligation. The trial judge in that case held that the employer, Merrill Lynch, bore vicarious liability for the conversion of RBC's records and for inducing the employees' breaches of their duties not to compete unfairly with RBC. The Court of Appeal overturned the damages against Merrill Lynch but did not comment on the issue of vicarious liability. However, on further appeal the Supreme Court of Canada reinstated the majority of the damages awarded by the trial court. See also section 4:15.
